Title: Practice-led project as a creative method to enhance theoretical knowledge in art and design education
Affiliations: Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Teaching theoretical subjects in art and design courses can be really puzzling since these subjects are considered as ‘boring’ and ‘not interesting.’ For lecturers who teach these kinds of subject, this situation is indeed a challenge that need to be solved. One method that can be shown as an attempt to solve this problem is the development of Western Art Review subject in Visual Communication Design course at Binus University, Indonesia. The main objective of this practice-led project is mostly about changing the general perspective that Western art is not about ‘learning’ art history but more about ‘understanding’ art story. By understanding the fundamental story of art, students will be able to relate the context of Western cultures into their design content. As a result, students manage to apply their knowledge into their artworks by creating illustrations based on specific Western art contexts, colours, and themes. They are also able to apply some famous paintings or artworks from Western art periods into new artworks by using different materials and techniques such as quilled paper art. Hopefully, these practice-led projects will become new methods for art and design students so that they will be able to develop their theoretical knowledge in a creative manner. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Practice-led; Projects; Prototype; Theoretical; Western art
References: Malins, J., Gray, C., Bunnell, K., (1995) Appropriate Research Methodologies for Artists, Designers and Craftpersons: Research as a Learning Process, p. 3. , Gray’s School of Art, Centre for Research in Art and Design; Schon, D., The Reflective Practitioners (1983) Basic Books; Boyd, J., (2015) Myths, Misconceptions, Problems and Issues in Arts Education, pp. 2-3. , Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; (2011), http://www.edvardmunch.org/the-scream.jsp, 1893 by Edvard Munch, Present www.EdvardMunch.org; Swift, F., (2014) Museums and Learning, Museum Narratives, Museum of London, , London; Wijaya, H., Reflections on Project: Interactive Book—40 World Faith Objects (2015) (The Significance of Religious Objects in Museums and Secular Lifestyles), p. 18. , University of Westminster; Ambrose, T., Paine, C., (2012) Museum Basics, p. 61. , 3rd edn., Routledge, London; Abbas, K., Hassan, Z.B., (2014) International Journal for Innovation Education and Research, 5; McNiff, S., (2008) Art Based Research, Handbook of the Arts in Qualitative Research: Perspectives, p. 33. , Methodologies, Examples and Issues, edited by J. Title: Exploring patterns through mosaic workshop as a learning method in building material subject
Affiliations: Interior Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Nediari, A., Interior Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Understanding materials as medium is one of significant process for students during their study in Interior Design course. As one of the biggest mosaic industry in Indonesia, Venus Tiles eager to give contribution in educational field, especially in developing knowledge about tiles as material to study in interior design. By distributing this specific product knowledge to students, industry elegantly inseminates its marketing strategy into educational institution. In Binus University, mosaic if one of topics that is essential to be learned by students in their fourth year of study. Students will gain knowledge through their learning experience, from installing tiles, developing conceptual and contextual design, enhancing sense of colours, and building their sensibility in aesthetical composition. Therefore, by applying this method, students will be able to gain knowledge theoretically and enhance their sensibility of space and design creativity while exploring materials in interior elements. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Francisching, D.K., (2014) Building Construction Illustrated, p. 4. , John Wiley & Sons, New Jersey; (2015), Solusi Kebutuhan Konstruksi dan Teknologi Bangunan, Info, Pikiran Rakyat, April (2012), Online Article, accessed on October; Pile, J.F., (2007) Interior Design, p. 42. , 4th edn., Pearson Prentice Hall, New Jersey; Demirkan, H., (2016) Design Studies Journal, 44, p. 28; Cohen, G.M., (2002) The Essential of Art History, 51p. , Research and Education Association, New York; Hombostel, C., (1991) Material, Types, Uses and Application, 92p. , 2nd edn., John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Canada; Wong, W., (1996) Principles of Form and Design, John Wiley & Sons, 44p. , Inc., Canada; Tile, V., (2002) Mosaic Installation, , http://venus-tiles.com/collections/, accessed on March 2016; McCulloch, J., (2010) Design in Black and White, 13p. , Images Publishing, Australia

Title: Understanding Chinese culture and tradition through observation in Chinese restaurant as a study case of informal education
Affiliations: Interior Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Graphics Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, P., Interior Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., Graphics Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Focused on how the application of Chinese ornaments in interior space, this paper tends to show that a study case based on observation and analysis can be contemporary methods of informal education to share knowledge about Chinese culture and tradition. As one of the oldest cultures in the world, Chinese culture—which consists of literary arts, architecture, and craft—has diverse philosophical interpretations. A Chinese restaurant, as a place to serve traditional Chinese food in public space, visibly holds a strong connection to Chinese culture. Moreover, art can become an attractive method to deliver aesthetic contents of Chinese philosophy, especially its symbolic interpretation. In a typical Chinese restaurant, the connection between art and tradition is represented through the aesthetic elements that act functionally with their specific and unique characteristics. Therefore, these characteristics can be observed and studied in order to enhance further knowledge about Chinese culture. Furthermore, the theoretical aspects of culture and aesthetic design can also expand the perspective of our contemporary society and relate their understanding about tradition and ethnicity, especially Chinese culture in Indonesia and other countries. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aesthetic; Chinese culture; Informal education; Interpretation; Philosophy
References: (2007) Jurnal Historisme, p. 24; , p. 1. , https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Chinese_symbols_1109.pdf, A British Museum Tour: Journey to the East, The British Museum Partnership, UK (2008-09); (2016) Vocabulary.Com, , https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/restaurant; Velamuriramakrishna, S., Modern thinking turns traditional food into $400 million business—case study: South Beauty Group The Korea Times, , http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2015/09/332_82990.html; http://www.britannica.com/topic/long; , p. 3. , https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Chinese_symbols_1109.pdf, A British Museum Tour: Journey to the East, The British Museum Partnership, UK (2008-09), Web. Title: Unique features of Indonesian Wayang in book ornament prototype through visual communication design perspective
Affiliations: Visual Communication Design, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Widyokusumo, L., Visual Communication Design, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Either as students who learn visual communication design or as professional graphic designers, most of the time, we need to see book as a reference; especially reference for visual elements that holds traditional context or design principles. Reference for visual elements will be useful to give inspiration in visual communication design outcomes, such as product design, poster, brochure, logo, or even in multimedia and animation. Wayang, a well-known Indonesian cultural heritage, needs to be preserved since its existence is slowly fading from contemporary life. This research will provide many aspects of wayang, such as historical, cultural, philosophical, and also from contemporary perspective through design perspective. The main focus of the book is about the wayang’s ornaments from Surakarta area. This research used exploration and experiment in design for its method. Outcomes from this research will become the source of inspiration and reference to create design products, which contain ‘local value’ with ‘contemporary spirits.’ Moreover, the main objective of developing the prototype of Indonesian wayang book ornament is to preserve a cultural heritage in the form of literature, so that we are also able to preserve the knowledge for our next generation in the future. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Wijaya, H., Reflections on project: Interactive book–40 world faith objects (2015) The Significance of Religious Objects in Museums and Secular Lifestyles, p. 4. , University of Westminster, London; (2014) Inscribed in 2008 (3.COM) on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity (Originally Proclaimed in 2003), , UNESCO, October; Dwiandiyanta, B., Yudi, A.B.M., Wijaya, M., Maslim, and Suyoto (2012) International Journal of Advanced Science and Technology, 43, p. 95; Wayang Sebagai Warisan Budaya Dunia (2008) Penerbit SIC; (2004), Wayang Sebagai Ungkapan Filsafat Jawa, Adita Pressindoesti, Yogyakarta; (1999), 2 (5). , Sena Wangi, Jakarta

Authors: Puspitasari D.G., Sabana S., Ahmad H.A., Wijaya H.
Title: The educational value of sang Pencerah film by Hanung Bramantyo: Aesthetic research of chiaroscuro
Affiliations: Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Sabana, S., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Ahmad, H.A., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Focused on how film can be efficient to deliver educational values through chiaroscuro, this paper shows a new dimension of seeing film as a media that can be equal with human ways of thinking. Both of these elements maximise memory, imagination, attention, emotion, and perception of values. Chiaroscuro is a lighting technique that emphasised in low-key lighting; a contrast boundary between light and dark area that gives influence emotion and cognition of viewers. Using Sang Pencerah film by Hanung Bramantyo as study case, we would discuss the background why chiaroscuro has a significant influence in developing reflective interpretation and specific value in film. The method of this research was based on Elsaesser and Hagener film theory and Charles S. Peirce’s theory of semiotics. Moreover, through this research, we found that film actually has a ‘form language’ as its own aesthetic language. Going beyond artistic value, chiaroscuro is able to reach philosophical aspect in life values, such as determination, peacefulness, and so on. Hopefully, this research will be able to contribute in the development of education aspect, especially in film studies. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Sugiharto, B., (2012) Humanisme Dan Humaniora, p. 343. , Jalasutra, Yogyakarta; Sugiharto, B., (2013) Untuk Apa Seni, p. 319. , Matahari, Bandung; Abel, R., (1988) French Film Theory and Criticism: A History/Anthology, 1, pp. 1907-1929. , Princenton University Press, Princenton, NJ; Pratista, H., (2008) Memahami Film, pp. 77-78. , Homerian Pustaka, Yogyakarta; Elsaesser, T., Hagener, M., (2010) Film Theory-An Introduction Throught the Senses, pp. 55-56. , Routledge, New York; Short, T.L., (2007) Peirce’s Theory of Sign, pp. 215-220. , Cambridge University Press, New York; Vasseleu, C., (2002) Textures of Light, pp. 5-6. , Routledge, New York

Title: Understanding the cultural and religious insights of Indonesia through “Drupadi Pandawa Diva” the masterpieces of F. Widayanto
Affiliations: Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The development of ceramic art in Indonesia has been increasing progressively for years. This paper will focus on F. Widayanto’s latest works “Drupadi Pandawa Diva” that has surprised the Indonesian art-loving community. As one of the most prominent ceramicist in Indonesia, F. Widayanto has verified his existence in the art fields for more than thirty years. In his 15th solo exhibition, F. Widayanto decided to choose Draupadi—one of the unique and strong characters from the grand epic Mahabharata—as his main subject. Even though epic of Mahabharata was originally come from ancient India, actually there are many versions of this epic around the world. One of the epic adaptations is come from Javanese Wayang (shadow puppet) play. This epic version was influenced by Islamic philosophy that was introduced in Java, Indonesia around the 13th century. Draupadi is a symbol of perfect womanhood: a strong woman who dares to challenge the strength and power of men. Her beautiful figure has inspired F. Widayanto to interpret and explore Draupadi’s character. F. Widayanto merged the original Indian version with Javanese Wayang version in order to produce his own Draupadi character. As a result, he managed to express his understanding and represented ‘figures’ of Draupadi that are lifted out of traditional art. These masterpieces are unique and can be interpreted in a variety of ways depend on the viewers’ perspective. By applying direct observation and literature review as her method, researcher intended to present the significance of ceramic art as an instrument to deliver Indonesian cultural and religious insights in contemporary way. Thus, this research is a case study of aesthetic project that can be used as a reference for future artists, ceramicists, and art connoisseurs in Indonesia and other countries. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Ceramic art; Draupadi; Interpretation; Javanese; Observation
References: Sedyawati, E., (2013) A Word of Welcome and Appreciation: F. Widayanto and His Works, Drupadi Pandawa Diva, 13p. , edited by F. Title: The importance of copies as the reminiscence of lost collections at Kenwood house
Affiliations: Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Kenwood House is a neoclassical villa on the edge of Hampstead Heath, London. The collections at Kenwood, as well as the architecture and interiors of Robert Adam, are of great historical value and cultural significance for England. English Heritage become responsible for the Iveagh Bequest at Kenwood in 1986. The main issues that will be discussed and emphasised in this paper is about the importance of copies (replicas) and authenticity of the collections that was carried out by English Heritage during the restoration project since for Kenwood House whose artefacts lost and dispersed at auction in 1922, replicas could be considered as a reminder of the originals. Thus, as the custodian, educator, regulator and advisor on the heritage assets, English Heritage aims to bring back the ‘wholeness’ of historic significance of Kenwood House by using both genuine objects and copies to create a more authentic 18th-century setting to support the concept of restoration that implies the returning of property to its original state. By focusing on a critical context for its research methodology, this paper will open to challenge and debate. Researcher tried to employ methodologies that could reflect her particular discipline-specific expertise: Visual Arts and Museum Studies. Therefore, this paper will provide a sample of review outcomes that could demonstrate another perspective of seeing and understanding the significance of copies or replicas in positive manner. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.

Title: Salt as subject of exploration to develop new perspective of contemporary art
Affiliations: Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Witabora, J., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The mysteries of life and nature are slowly revealed through the development of knowledge, which gives us consciousness and further insight about our relation with nature. In the world of art, life and nature do not only become the source of inspiration, but also become the object of reality that can be responded truthfully. By trying to understand the relation, human may open greater understanding and new imagination of life and nature. Based on this notion, researchers chose salt, one of the most important minerals on earth, as the main focus of this paper. Salt, as a source of life and energy, is essential for all living creatures and humankind. It is an important element and commodity of human life and civilisation in the world. Using a practice-based research and experimental art as its methods, this research will focus on how salt as object can be seen as a subject of art. This exploration intended to verify researchers’ contemplation that art and science can be explored without boundaries of scientific perspective. Through this study, researchers worked in team to find answer about life through salt philosophically, one as an artist and one as an observer. Therefore, this research can become a new mixture of practice-based study between artist and observer, also new perspective of contemporary visual between art and science. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Contemporary art; Exploration; Life; Nature; Salt
References: Puspitasari, D., (2013) Jurnal Dimensi, 11, p. 40; Puspitasari, D., (2013) Jurnal Dimensi, 11, p. 26; Candy, L., (2006) Practice Based Research: A Guide, p. 3. , CCS Report VI; Kaprow, A., (2003) Essays on the Blurring of Art and Life, pp. 68-69. , University of California Press, London; Kowan, A.M., Deep sea hydrothermal vents (2013) National Geographic Education, , http://education.nationalgeographic.org/media/deepsea-hydrothermal-vents/, edited by Julie Brown, National Geographic Society, March; Oparin, A.I., (2003) The Origin of Life on Earth, , Dover Publication Inc. Title: Humanism in the names of characters in Sawung Kampret film by Dwi Koendoro
Affiliations: School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper provides study on structural elements of the names of characters in Sawung Kampret film, which was adapted from Legenda Sawung Kampret comic. This study is interesting because of two things: First, comic and its adaptation film are created and directed by the same person, Dwi Koendoro; Second, it is the first academic study on film adaptation of Indonesian comic. Through the structural methods by Ferdinand de Saussure and the clock of character theory by Jens Eder, there are some interesting findings. One of those is the names of characters that were not chosen randomly so that they will sound hilarious, instead those name are significant elements to unify the narrative structure in film. An element of comedy in the characters’ name is related with interpretation and moral values. Therefore, as the final results, we are able to conclude that the characters’ names in Sawung Kampret film are fictional being with the symbolisation of humanism. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Comic adaptation; Film; Humanism; Name of characters
References: Lafevre, P., (2000) Incompatible Visual Ontologies? The Problematic Adaptation of Drawn Image, Film and Comic Books, p. 27. , Association of American University Presses, Missisippi; Pratista, H., (2008) Memahami Film, 43p. , Homerian Pustaka, Yogyakarta; Eder, J., (2010) Berghahn Journals, 4, p. 6; Setiawan, M.N., (2002) Menakar Panji Koming, Tafsiran Komik Karya Dwi Koendoro Pada Masa Reformasi Tahun 1998, 59p. , PT Kompas Media Nusantara, Jakarta; Saidi, A.I., (2008) Narasi Simbolik Seni Rupa Kontemporer Indonesia, pp. 42-45. , Isacbook, Yogyakarta; Eder, J., (2010) Berghahn Journals, 4, p. 16; Eder, J., (2010) Berghahn Journals, 4, p. 23; Metz, C., (1974) Film Language: A Semiotics of the Cinema, pp. 36-67. , edited by M. Authors: Puspitasari D.G., Sabana S., Ahmad H.A., Wijaya H.
Title: Modernism in Sang Pencerah film directed by Hanung Bramantyo
Affiliations: Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Sabana, S., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Ahmad, H.A., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., Visual Communication Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: As a product of Modernism, film has an ideological power in constructing mentality and intellectuality of society. On the other hand, modernity is more focused on ratio as the core of civilisation and stressed on emotive aspect as subordinate point. Hanung Bramantyo’s film Sang Pencerah is an ideological reflection of developing civilisation, which based on the classification of binary opposition between emotive aspect as darkness and ratio as enlightenment. Through the structural semiotics of Ferdinand de Saussure as a method, Sang Pencerah film will be studied in order to signify the classification of two opposite eras and their ideological contexts. From the analysis results, researchers found out that Sang Pencerah film was not just presenting a story of K. H. Ahmad Dahlan as a significant character of Islamic history in Indonesia, but far-reaching into a topic of modernism versus tradition in many aspects of life. Definition of the advancement in the film is a linear contrast compares to the Western modernism that emphasises more to ratio. Therefore, Sang Pencerah film is obviously a product of modernism. Hopefully, the outcomes of this research will be useful to enhance social studies in general society, especially in film. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Sugiharto, B., (2013) Untuk Apa Seni, p. 309. , Matahari, Bandung; Sugiharto, B., (2013) Untuk Apa Seni, p. 324. , Matahari, Bandung; Saidi, A.I., Batas Hati dan Rasio Dalam Keyakinan Beragam (2012) Jurnal Sosioteknologi, p. 70. , Ganesha FSRD-ITB, Bandung; http://www.britannica.com/topic/cogito-ergo-sum, Encyclopædia Britannica (2016), 04 March 2016; Giddens, A., (2003) Masyarakat Post Tradisional, p. 8. , ed by Alie Noer, IRCiSoD, Yogyakarta; Saidi, A.I., (2008) Narasi Simbolik Seni Rupa Kontemporer Indonesia, pp. 42-44. , ISACBOOK, Yogyakarta; Saidi, A.I., Batas Hati dan Rasio Dalam Keyakinan Beragam (2012) Jurnal Sosioteknologi, p. 80. , Ganesha FSRD-ITB, Bandung

Authors: Puspitasari D.G., Sabana S., Ahmad H.A., Wijaya H.
Title: Chiaroscuro in visual narrative of Sang Pencerah film by Hanung Bramantyo
Affiliations: Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Sabana, S., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Ahmad, H.A., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Film is a media that can develop the mentality and intellectuality of its audience. Thus, it is significant to understand how to construct the depth of interpretation and acquire the efficiency of storytelling and aesthetic visual narrative in film. Chiaroscuro is an artistic lighting technique in film that emphasising light as a significant aspect of storytelling and pictorial composition in film. The boundary between dark and light area that is produced can give dramatical effect and emotional depth in film visualisation. By choosing Hanung Bramantyo’s Sang Pencerah as a study case, researchers can identify the narrative structure, role and interpretation of chiaroscuro artistic lighting in film. This research used narrative discourse analysis as the main approach that was based on Gerard Genette’s narrative concept and Charles Sanders Peirce’s semiotics theory. Result of analysing the film shows that Sang Pencerah is a film with linear structure with three chapters, which used the lighting aspect to bind the plot points of story. In conclusion, chiaroscuro in visual narrative of Sang Pencerah film is a manisfestation of cinematic metaphor that was based on cultural value. This value can enhance both the effectivity of storytelling and the aesthetic aspect of film, which also significant to develop uniqueness and identity of Indonesian film. Hopefully, the outcomes of this research can give contribution in film studies, especially in developing knowledge about lighting. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Malkiewicz, K., (2012) Film Lighting: Talks with Hollywood’s Cinematographers and Gaffers, 1p. , Touchstone, New York; Vacche, A.D., (2009) Chiaroscuro: Caravaggio, Bazin, Storaro, Senses of Cinema, Online Resources, , Retrieved: 22 January 2016; Lally, D., Digital Chiaroscuro: Transforming a Classical Style through Digital Animation, 12p. , Drexel University, Thesis, USA; Pratista, H., (2008) Memahami Film, 79p. , Homerian Pustaka, Yogyakarta; Genette, G., (1995) Narrative Discourse: An Essay in Method, 25p. , Cornell University Press, New York; Short, T.L., (2007) Peirce’s Theory of Sign, pp. 215-220. , Cambridge University Press, New York; Pratista, H., (2008) Memahami Film, pp. 46-47. , Homerian Pustaka, Yogyakarta
Correspondence Address: Puspitasari, D.G.; Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Indonesia

Authors: Saidi A.I., Puspitasari D.G., Wijaya H.
Title: Interpreting the cultural values of learning space design based on traditional education system in Indonesia
Affiliations: Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Saidi, A.I., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Puspitasari, D.G., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Teaching and learning are not merely about process of conveying knowledge, but more as a model to form ideal educational subjects i.e., learning participants with characters. This research will focus on the relation between the founding characters of educational participants with the learning space design based on traditional education system in Indonesia. The learning space design is considered as a structure of signs that has its own interpretation and values, which then led this research to apply semiotics as its analysis method. The significant finding from the analysis is the existence of ideal values behind the founding characters process that can be acknowledged culturally by educational participants as the products of their society. Moreover, the learning space design is not considered as a merely physical material, but more as a mental substance of learning and teaching process. Therefore, based on the findings of research, researchers can conclude that local aspects are essential to be concerned and studied in order to actualise new perspective in Indonesian educational system that is based on traditional and cultural values. Also, through this study, researchers aim to inspire people and communities to retrace Indonesian heritage in order to enhance the quality of education in the present time. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Barker, C., (2005) Cultural Studies, Theory and Practice, 373p. , Sage Publications, London; Gaines, E., (2006) Journal of Creative Communications, 1, p. 2; Shroeder, J.E., (2002), Visual Comsumption, Routledge. Authors: Puspitasari D.G., Sabana S., Ahmad H.A., Wijaya H.
Title: Reflectivity of contemporary life in Sang Pencerah film directed by Hanung Bramantyo
Affiliations: Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; School of Design, Bina Nusantara Universit, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Sabana, S., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Ahmad, H.A., Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara Universit, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Historical film is not only a representation of actual chronicle in the past, but also can be interpreted as a reflectivity of actual problems in contemporary life. Unfortunately, in fact, historical film is treated as a merely product that conveys historical narrative that only useful as a source of past knowledge. Consequently, a study about reflectivity of contemporary life in historical film is significant in order to enrich viewers’ knowledge and understanding. By using Sang Pencerah film that was directed by Hanung Bramantyo as a study case, the focus of research is about the association of reality between past chronicles with modern life and its involvement with the complexity of contemporary issues. Through the analysis of James Paul Gee and Gerard Genette’s narrative discourse, it can be concluded that Sang Pencerah film is a historical film which not only focused on the past uprising of K. H. Ahmad Dahlan but also represented new values of past events, significant visions and answers for actual issues of humankind in Indonesia. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Abrams, M.H., (1980) The Mirror and the Lamp, Romantic Theory and the Critical Tradition, 31p. , Oxford University Press; Sugiharto, B., (2013) Untuk Apa Seni, 321p. , Matahari, Bandung; Gee, J.P., (2005) An Introduction to Discourse Analysis, Theory and Method, 21p. , Routledge, London and New York; Genette, G., (1995) Narrative Discourse, 25p. , Translated by J. E. Lewin, Cornell University Press, New York; Saidi, A.I., (2012) Batas Hati Dan Rasio Dalam Keyakinan Beragam, 80p. , Jurnal Sosioteknologi, Ganesha FSRD-ITB, Bandung, ISSN 1858-3474; Schroeder, J.E., (2002) Visual Consumption, pp. 141-159. , Routledge, London and New York
Correspondence Address: Puspitasari, D.G.; Fakultas Seni Rupa dan Desain, Indonesia

Title: The significance of religious objects in museums as a cultural reflection
Affiliations: School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: As the main ‘identity’ in Eastern culture, religion has a significant role in human life. This paper will discuss specifically about the difference of religious and spiritual perspective between Western and Eastern culture that influence museums’ perspective in displaying their religious objects. Western culture tend to be more contemporary, especially in engaging museums’ objects. Religious artefacts or objects are treated as ‘beautiful’ and ‘historical’ objects in museums. These objects hold valuable information, but also need to be appreciated from their ‘spiritual value.’ By connecting and comparing the display of religious objects in museums and in their place of origin (temple or sacred place), we could get the sense of meaning and the change of value, which led us to understand the background of each culture and how important it is as the ‘identity’ of objects or even the ‘identity’ of culture and civilisation. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Museums; Religious objects; Western and eastern culture
References: Hermans, C.A.M., (2013) Journal of Empirical Theology, 26, p. 165; Silberman, I., (2005) Journal of Social Issues, 61, p. 641; Morgan, D., (2012) Religion and Visuality in America: Material Economies of the Sacred, the Cambridge History of Religions in America: Pre-Columbian Times to 1790, 1, pp. 748-780. , Cambridge University Press; Jordanova, L., (1989) Objects of Knowledge: A Historical Perspective on Museums, pp. 23-25. , The New Museology, edited by P. Title: The aesthetic sensibility of Nirmana Dwimatra through design methods based on stimuli of senses (Study case of estetika rasa and aroma project)
Affiliations: School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Puspitasari, D.G., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, H., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This research will discuss about the structure of ‘Estetika Rasa and Aroma’ (aesthetic taste and smell) project using case study that is idealised and visualised by the first semester students of Nirmana Dwimatra (Two- Dimensional Form) module from Visual Communication Design course, Undergraduate level at Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia. This study is interesting since it is based on synesthesia of sight, taste and smell. Using the structural approach from Ferdinand de Saussure and the theory from Primaldi Tabrani, creativity process and relation between elemental forms that referred to a modulation of link stimulus could be identified. There were also other discoveries about how the elemental form structure from aesthetic taste and smell could relate to each other and construct an art union with various interpretations. Besides, it was discovered that the creation process was not only a single method, but also an accumulative of expression and experience from psychology and cognitive approach in a total bodily experience. Hopefully, this research could become a contemporary way of nirmana dwimatra module that able to develop and create aesthetic sensibility as the intellectual basic for art and design studies since this is the first study that emphasise the relation between experience and visual outcomes. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bodily experience; Elemental form; Nirmana; Synesthesia
References: Cassirer, E., (1944) An Essay on Man, 235p. , Yale University Press; Saidi, A.I., (2008), pp. 42-45. , Narasi Simbolik Seni Kontemporer Indonesia, ISACBOOK, Yogyakarta; Tabrani, P., (2006) Kreativitas Dan Humanitas: Sebuah Studi Tentang Peranan Kreativitas Dalam Perikehidupan Manusia, pp. 280-291. , Jalasutra, Yogyakarta
Correspondence Address: Puspitasari, D.G.; School of Design, Indonesia
